transcript.content: Richard Ashcroft, "Science of Silence" on XFM 104.9. I love that.
He's one of my favorite artists now, I just think... I- he's so- I don't know why he's not ballistic.
He's got everything. He's got- one of our best rock stars.
Ehhh, Karl Pilkington, over there. (Loudly) Big day today!

Yeh, for Karl. He hasn't been looking forward to it, he's been whingin' in the week. A couple of things: he thinks he's overworked, he thinks he- he thinks he's overworked here and he's stressed and he's got to do DIY. MTV are coming im- in, right, to give him the chance of a- a lifetime to do a- just a little screen test and he's going, "Well, I'm not gonna look good, am I? They're not gonna-", I go, "Why?", he said, "Well, I've got a round head and I'll be wearin' headphones".
And uhh, he's- he's not made an effort, he thinks, "Ooh, I'll put 'em off", he said, "They won't even press 'Record'". He's got a spot on his head.
Karl, you're not looking forward to it? You're not excited about it? It's a great oppurtunity.
No but look what's happened to people like, umm, Jeremy Speak or whatever his name is and all that.
Y- you're- you're makin' it in the industry and you've got- you've got something to give, he- he happened to be around while they were filming an airport.
All right, the other one then, who's on a boat.
Although at least she had a skill. She had a skill, you know, she can sing. You know...
Well she- she's c- I d- I d- I think it can all go wrong... d'ya know what I mean?

Well of course it can. So can sitting in your little room moanin' about nothing happening in the world. You know he- he wanted to stop "Educating Ricky" cuz nothing had happened. He said- he said, "Look what happened last week - I scoured the net...", he said, "all I found was a dog in a car wash and a parrot and a vicar."
I'll tell you what: there aint much more going on this week.
Well you're talkin' sh- listen, me and Steve... yesterday, we took a day off to prove you wrong and we've come up with two of the most incredible things.
I told you about- they're amazing. So there are things out there or s- just- j- but go for truth- go for truth and science and discovery--
Yeah, that's what I do. That's what I do, yeah. Yeah.
Fact is- is stranger than fiction. You don't have to resert- revert to, sort of like, God and ghosts.
I know, yeah. I know, yeah.
Do you know what I mean?
But the funny thing is... do you know, like, the last couple of weeks I been sayin' there's not much going on?
I found out, when I was looking that there was a day in 1930... right, it was a Good Friday, there was no news, there was nothing going on...
They had to put a music video on or something.
On the telly. Because there was nothing going on.
Play a record. We're gonna play some classic tracks today. This is d- "Debaser".

Pixies, "Debaser". I was looking forward to playing that, came in, said, "Karl, play that-", lookin-... he put it on... uhh... Lauren just called through and said we played that in the last half hour.
So, what is the point of having a producer if he doesn't check things out. So, I mean, it's a good track, I mean, I'm sorry if you heard that twice in the last hour.
Go on, go on. You were going to say sommat?
So you expect me to listen to everything all the time? I've been running around- I get in early on a Saturday--
Well you got in around the same time as me.
I g- I went out and bought you some biscuits, so you're happy...
I sorted what prizes we're gonna give away, I've been running to the library getting you certain tracks--
I can't listen all the time. I'm doing me best!
Ahh, I'm just not sure it's good enough, Karl.
I mean, I'm worried when MTV come in, if they've heard this kind of shoddy production, they're gonna start to wonder why--
Well they play the same songs every five minutes anyway.
Yeah sorry you're so overworked because you were on Zoe Ball's show talking.
Oh hello! What's going on here?!
He was excl- he was exclusively to be on our show--
Well I was in the ca- I was in the car--
I seem to remember, Rick, he was- he was a nobody--
That got a chance to come on air and talk about things and now he's getting auditioned for MTV!
And guess what he was- guess what he was talkin' about on Zoe's show.
All the jellyfish stuff and all that... kind of stuff...
Material that he did on this show!
I phoned in- I phoned in, right, and I went, "Stop doing material on Zoe's B-", right. He just hung up on me.
Well I had a job to do!
Who do you think you are?!
Your ego has just gone through the roof!
Hang on a minute. Hang on a minute.
I had a job to do in the week, they asked me to drive the desk for Zoe, right.
Zoe... if she talks to ya, you can't just ignore her!
Who does she think she is? You made a promise to us - a pact - that  you are our, kind of...
Yeah, but what do I do? If someone takes time off, I've got to do it. It's me job.
Yeah but you don't have to talk. You don't have to use--
You're the head of production. We've given you this special gig. This is like taking you out weekends...
And we- you know, if we find out you're gettin' too much excitement in the week, we'll have to just calm it down...
Well that's it anyway, it was only last week.
Do you know, I feel like, kind of sullied, I feel betrayed. It's like you were having an affair behind our backs--
He was doin' all the stuff, he was doin' all this- like, "Ooh, yeah, jellyfish and this and jelly fish that..."
Yeah because she was askin'! And I thought it was a good way of promotin' this show, actually.
Yeah, I did at some point.
Did ya? What did you say?
I just said, uhh, "More about that on Saturday afternoons".
So you talked twice - I only heard you talk once. So you're talkin' all the time, are you?
Well, about five times in the week.
In the full week - five times.
And one- it was just stuff that--
You could never be a monk, could ya? Chattin' away all the time.
I blame Ball as well, to be honest.
I feel Ball is slightly responsible for it.
She can't find her own, you know, gibbon to get on the show.
She can't find her own, kind of, you know, loser, then... don't start stealing ours.
Yeah, maybe we'll get Fatboy Slim in.
Next... Saturday. If you're listenin', umm, Slim--
What's his name? Ernie or something?
He probably wouldn't change his name. Ernie Cook
Ernie Cook, that's it yeah. (Laughing) That's great!
Coming up today, uhh, we have got "Educating Ricky"...
Rrright. Is this the last one? You've promised it might be.
Uhhm, I believe there's a book out... that might help me with this feature--
So we'll see how it goes, we might- I was thinkin' of new features in the week. I've got, uhh--
What did I come up with? I wanted to do "Celebrity Fact Club".
I've just got to get some celebrities in first.
Before we can kick that off so maybe in the new year.
Maybe. Right, and I've also got, uhh--
Yeah. Maybe you could sell that to Zoe's show!
And, umm, I'm also thinkin', "Through The RicKey Hole".
No, you've just got the title again, haven't ya?! Yeah. Okay, play a record.
So, uhh, "Rockbusters" coming up as well. All right?
We're playing some great music today, Rick--
I wonder if we should maybe... uh, you know, it's getting towards Christmas--
Think about others. Should we dedicate this show to all the people in the world who maybe are less priviledged and less, uhh, fortunate than us.
Um, d- do the prizes for the, uhh--
Prizes? Okay. (Walking Away From Microphone) So screw those who are less fortunate is what TV's Ricky Gervais thinks.
Uhmm, Rick, I know you're a big fan, uhh, of the likes of Brian Adams, (Laughs) Robert Palmer, uh, Alien Ant Farm and, uh, obviously, ehmm, ZZ Top.
And so you'll be enjoying "The Best Air Guitar Album In The World".
Volume 1 (Coughs) wasn't enough. There wasn't enough.

Again, we seem to be able to give one of these away every week. Are you just not sending these out? I mean, these are the same prizes we started this game with, I think, a couple of weeks back. Are you just not sending the prizes out?
Yeah, but I want to give, like, more people a chance cuz if- if one week they listen in and think, "God, I wouldn't mind winnin' that--"
If you- if you've got more copies of it, they'll go, "Well, I'll listen next week."
So again this is, uh, one of those, uhm, "The Best Songs You've Heard On An Advert Ever" albums.
Mainly mobile phone adverts, yeah. Although there is the, uh, Smashmouth one which is used in the Ford Fiesta TV advert.
Oh yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. "Walking On The Sun" or something?
Uhm, the Smashing Pumpkins album that we've given away in the past again.
Obviously got a bulk order of those that can't shift them. Uhhmm, "Wild Weather", I don't know who's interested in this. This is, uh--
Is that a double box set VHS of different weather?!
There's two cassette tapes there, it's presented by Donal MacIntyre.
THAT is amazing! How long is- that's a--
"It's a thrilling trip with the most exciting forces of our wild and turbulent world. Clouds, rainstorms--"
So- so I'm right in saying it's- it's a double VHS video set of different weather?
There's stuff like tornadoes an' that!
Yep, no, it's got- I mean it includes the fastest winds--
The hottest desert, ehm and the biggest rain machine on the planet. That's on there, I think you have to--
Ohhh, God. I- I wonder if they're- I hope they're bringing out another box set... "Soil"
And, uhh, and this maybe of interest - I read good reviews of the, uhh- the DVD of this - it's, uhh, a two-disc set: "The Wicker Man"--
The classic seventies film. It's got a bunch of extras on there.
That is actually quite a good film.
So, that- that's actually worth having. I'd probably throw the rest away or pawn that over on someone at Christmas.
But "The Wicker Man" get that on DVD and it's, yeah, quite- it's very interesting.
Yeah. But, you'll enjoy that. So, uhh--
Brilliant. Well, let's- let-l- I say get the ball rolling now.
I don't know, I mean, tease them, Rick, don't, you know- don't s- don't, sort of, spunk all the good stuff early on, I mean--
You- you can say, "Spunk". I can't.
Well- well we've got, ummm- actually it's quite good, movin' it about because we might have some new listeners here.
Ehhm, right, okay, so if you haven't heard it before I give you some initials- it work- you know it's like initials of an artist or a band--
And- and a cryptic clue to who the band is. It's two easy ones, one difficult one.
First one is: uhmm, "That'll never get off the ground."
"That'll never get off the ground". The initials?
"That'll never get off the ground", is the clue. And--
Yeah? Right and then you've got, uhhm, "That woman's got her husband's gloves and a pair of her own".

"That woman has got a pair of her husband's gloves and she's got a pair of her own". That's H.H. All right? That's a bit of a difficult one. And then the, uhh- the last one: "You'll get a lo-", uhhh, "You'll get a right load of bacon off them!" Right?
"... a right load of bacon off them".
"You'll get a right load of bacon off of them".
"You'll get- you'll get a right load of bacon off them".
So, first one: "That'll never get off the ground" - L.Z., uhh, "That woman has got her husband's gloves and she's got a pair of her own", that's H.H.
And, uhh, "You'll get a right load of bacon off them!", that's L. So...
And it's an email only competition.
Email only, uhh, [emailÂ protected] and we pick a winner before the end... So...
And you can win those great prizes--
And you can win... "The Wicker Man"--
I'll tell you what: you remember how we always play, like, great music usually?
Ah, you're not- you're not gonna- have you--
I'm gonna do it. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. This is David Bowie - "Drive-In Saturday".
(Eating) Pwha- I'm in the- I'm having the same problem.
I know. Been eating a biscuit.
That's a great track isn't it?
A crash course for the ravers, eh? That's what this show is, innit Karl? Crash course for the ravers. The tune in and they go, "That's- that's so cool. I wish I was like Karl Pilkington."
Yeah. Definitely. You forgot to read your mum's clues out, didn't ya?
This is just for fun only. This is Karl's mum's. She, uhh, she listened one week and now she sends him a little example of what-- "Rockbusters" every week.
She's got, umm... what did she send? Umm--
"This group would go well with your Christmas dinner".
Yeh. Ehmm, "They make a few good cupboards".
The Carpenters. I was thinking of EMF.
Uhh, "This group thinks of lots of things".
"This group thinks of lots of things".
I think they're the best ones.
Well, if they're the best ones, let's hear the others.
N-N-N- Karl, obviously we want the worst ones then!
Uhh, here's one more: uhh, "She'd really like Blackpool".
"She'd really like Blackpool"... "She'd really like Blackpool".
Right, so uhh, there's uh, a--
Does she write anything else in the letter? Or does she just send them on, like, a- scawled on the back of--
You know, I don't know, a till receipt.
She did with the first one, now it's just- just the "Rockbusters". So...
She doesn't bother asking how you are or...
And I speak to her in the week on the phone so...
What kind of conversations would you have then with your mum? What kind of stuff--
What do you say? Do you moan about how overworked you are and stuff to her?

Uh,,,,, I just- I mean, they're always surprised when I'm getting in late and that. It's like, you know, "What have you done today?", "Oh, I'm just getting home from work", and it's half past eight at night.
A lot of people get home at half eight, Karl. Next.
It's, you know, uhh... just sayin', "How's the flat goin'?"
Askin' me dad some DIY tips the other day.
Uhhm, you know, usual sort of stuff--
You talk about with your mum and dad, really.
Uhhh, talkin' about the bisons with 'em.
I was wachin', uhh- did you watch "The Mammals" in the week?
I was thinkin', actually, right, with all this MTV stuff--
If there's one reason why I'd like to do it--
Is... I was watchin' Attenborough, the- the mammals program - I reckon I could do something like that.
And just have- have, like, me and instead of Attenborough y-you know, a young, sort of, fresh person.
Uhh, watching, like uhhm, certain animals and saying, "Do we need these?"
(Laughing) OH God! What'd you call it, "Death on Earth"?
That- that's amazing! "Do we need these?"
No, no, cuz there's loads of stuff--
And the audience at home- vote- would there be some kind of telephone vote?
Yeah, yeah, like a vote-out system.
It's like, Att- something interesting that Attenborough was saying the other night on uhh--

On Jonathan Ross' show, on his telly show, right, was sayin', uhh, he said, "You could... take all the humans off the earth and it would carry on but take, like, some animals off it and mammals and that... you got problems on your hands".
So it's like, the question is, "Do we need these?...Is that part of the big thing". Like jellyfish--
So which mammals in particular were you watching evolve?
You talked about it on Zoe Ball's show, didn't ya?
Which mammals, uhh, were you thinking we don't need when you watched the show the other night?
Any in particular that you thought, (Whispers) "We don't need them, they're not of interest."
Well I like- I like whales but I don't know what they do.
And they're- they're taking up quite a lot of room.
(Laughing) "They're taking up quite a lot of room"!
But, like, uhhmm... jellyfish I looked into because...
You know, I was talkin' about 'em. And, uhh, they were sayin' they've got no eyes, no heart--
Ehhm, they're blind and they do about 33 miles a day.
So it's like, do we need them? Could we clear them out?
What- that- that would be the program: what- what- "Right, we'll get rid of them, uhh, next week we'll be looking at...", uhh--
(Laughing) I think it's genius. Honestly, I think it's genius. And like, goin' along, sort of like, pickin' up sea anemones and goin'- and just lobbin' 'em into the sea.
Well, what do you think about MTV doin' that and then I just, in between the bits--
That relates to fish. So I could play, like, Phish--
That rock guy or The Animals.
Yeah. Or, uhh, what else could I--
What other songs have got animals in them?
The Monkees. I could play The Monkees.
Yeah, there's about a million so let's not start this.
No but, d'ya know what I mean? So--
So- but- so, "Do We Need This".
So MTV flies you around the world--
To the most incredible exotic locations, you sort of climb up a tree or whatever next to - I don't know what lives up a tree - some kind of rare parrot--
You look at that, you say, "Oh, it's colorful, it's interesting--"
Oh, you like sloths though, don't ya?
No, they just live up trees but I'd say, "Do we need them?"
(Laughing Slightly) What do you mean, "What do they do?". What do you want from an animal? Carpentry? What do you want?
Well, I don't- I don't like scorpions, right--
But then, I found out they look after those, uhh, those monkey things.
Whatever. Well, all right, yeah, then lizards. They look after lizards.
But- but, "Do you need the lizard?", would be your next question.
Yeah,  because the local people made shoes out of 'em.
But not when the scorpion protect them, they didn't.
All right, we don't need 'em then.

So- and so ultimately you- would anyone decide, I mean, do the animals, kind of, get a chance to mount a case for their survival? I mean is there maybe someone that comes in that come into their corner and defends them?
Yeah- yeah- n- I'd have- I'd have like a David Attenborough-type character--
Who says, "Well it does this..." and I'll go, "Yeah, but do we need that doin'?"

Okay so what- what does an animal need to do in order for you to feel that it sort of gets a chance of- of life. I mean, like a pet, like an animal like a dog, maybe or a cat, I mean they give a certain affection to its owner, is that a valid, uhh, reason to survive?
I mean, sayin' that though, blind people use dogs, so they are useful.
So dogs are useful. St. Bernards, they can save people - don't they - in snowy weather.
Farmers use dogs. Yeah. Cats... I'd have to think about it.
What I'm saying is- what I'm saying is, something that will affect the world.
Right, I think you'll find everything does. I think you'll find everything does.
I'm not sure what effect he's having on the world.
I'll tell you what, though Steve, right, did you watch "The Mammals"?
They had, uhh- they had bison on it.
The weirdest looking things you've ever seen.
Again, you're on dangerous ground, here, Karl.
No, no, no, no, they've really got a- it's like... decide what you want to look like.
It's just a mismatch of stuff. It's got a really big hairy head--
Sort of, bald at the back--
It sounds like someone you went to school with.
Coldplay - In My Place Begins To Play
From the album "Original Pirate Material", that's obviously The Streets and, uh, an album track from that, "It's Too Late". Fantastic isn't it?
I know everyone's raving about it being, you know, one of the albums of the year, but it is, I think.
It's great. That's brilliant. I l- love- love the backing as well.
It's just so good- the- the lyrics are- things he come- w- i- t-  ah, they're my favorite band of the year. Uhm, next week then, we'll do all our favorite songs of the year, shall we?
Mm, no I think it's got to be two week's time, isn't it?
Yeah, I'm away next week as well.
What do you mean you're away next week? What are you doing, Zoe Ball's show?
I'm going- going up north again.
So Claire's going to be here with you.
What are you doing up north?
I bet he's a party animal. I've heard they really kick off. Don't they? Is it, yeah? Mental?
Ooh, he's all stressed cuz the lady from MTV's here. She's gonna film his little face.
The thing- the things he said in the week, he was so worried. He was going- worried about the spot on his head- that won't come out- just so- she's got your best side.
Just so she stays on that side. That's all right.

(Laughing Slightly) Yeah. The camera's out. Look, he's getting nervous now. Okay Karl, ignore the camera, okay. Just ignore the camera, okay. Now, me and Steve have done our research for ya and we've got two amazing things to tell you. What should I tell him first - about the baby or the...crabs?
Well they're both equally fascinating, so you- you choose.

Uhm, I'll tell you the crab thing first, right. Uhm, we- Steve actually saw this thing in The Guardian, in the week, uh, about a research thing and then we looked up- we looked into it on Friday and it is incredible. Right, listen to this. There's, uhh, a thing in umm- umm in a bay in, umm, uhh, New England, right, where it's like the biggest, um, uh- they make silicon chips and stuff for computers, right. And cuz of the data protection thing, after they've d- done them, because they have to destroy the plates, right, where the information's, sort of, put onto them. But they're still flakes of silcon, they sort of grind it down straight away and some of the flakes got into the bay, okay. But, some of the information's still on the- even the s- slight granules of silicon. Anyway, gets in the water and silicon is rather like, um, a carbon derivative. They reckon if there'd been life on another planet that wasn't carbon-based, it'd be silcon-based. Cuz... simple sugars and protoz- it's just COH and that and it can work with silcon, right. Anyway, the crabs have been taking up- this gets underwater, and they- they looked out on the beach and, uhh- over the years the crabs had started, umm, sort of, putting themselves in formations like geometric forma- and they couldn't work it out why they were doing this. And uhh, when they put them in the experiment they, sort of, like, chopped 'em up and they found they'd taken on silicon... and it had, sort of, got into their brain and they were downloading information - they actually- they picked up little things because it's just chemical, umm, you know like, w- electrical impulses it'd... got information off the silcon chip and they were interfacin' it but - this is the amazing thing - one bloke, sort of, thought of this and he thought, "Well, if- if this is a simple computer, the brain, if it's just a simple, sort of, electrical ... thing, then maybe there's- there's...", you know, "we could get it down". So what- what they did is they made a thing called, "a bio-interface" and they- they put it into the crab's brain, just a really simple brain, into its medula oblongada, right. And it got impulses from it and they were getting... like computer readou- just flashes of like symbols and geometric things, right, on this screen to read the crab's brain and it was stuff like, you know, fragments of a, uhm--
Wha- what made them do this in the first place?

Because they saw- they saw the crabs behaving differently. They were behaving differently to each other. They were just like- they- you know, intelligent and they were, sort of, solving problems and all this sort of stuff. Anyway, when they downloaded the- the thing, it was like a- there was, uhm, uhh, they found- s- they f- they found one of the secretaries' names... where it had been on the silcon chip where it was just, like, a flash of a computer screen. But the most amazing thing is - they downloaded a memory, right. It was like a- like a snapshot where it'd been burnt onto the retina of the crab - just a snapshot or sommat - and it was like a picture of the beach, like, a couple of years ago, right. And they also j- i- i- incredible it was like, just a digital black and white, sort of thing, so they could see what the crab had seen.
So, wha- what are they doing with them now, then?

Well they think- this is the- this is the upshot - they think they could use it as spy crabs cuz they could put these- get these crabs- al- also, the other thing is as generations went on, right- so they put a crab in the- the sea or something, right, uh, lots of crabs in and then as generations went on, a- a new born crab- they downloaded the memory and it had the memories of its great-great-great-great-great- all together. It had every memory that any crab that had been related to it beforehand. Because it passed it on- it just passed it on.
So not even ones that had been eating the silicon stuff.
These are just ones that have had kids.
And they know every- so you'd know everything your great-gre- everything right the way back.
So would that work if- if we ate silicon?

Well they can use them for all sorts of things though. I mean, that- that's what's incredible, I mean, I don't know- I don't know how you'd train it particularly, I'm not sure how you would train but I'm assuming that they can- if they can- if they can do it that way, then presumably they can--
Which they can then plant in it, if you like, within it- within its, sort of, food, as it were.
Also if you get them onto enemy beaches--
And you can get it- yeah.
You'd have like a thousand digital cameras, just--
Just sneaking around. You know, if you can get, you know--
Osama Bin Laden or someone just crawling around on the sand.
They don't- they don't understand the information they've got though.
No, they don't know they're doing it.

So they're not- it's not like- you could torture them and they wouldn't be able to, sort of, give you the information because they wouldn't know what the information they had because they're just like a computer.
But the crab- the cra- the crab- the first crab they downloaded, they just kept seeing the same picture of a big crab feedin' which they--
That's what? Like its mother crab or something?
Yeah. It was memories of it as a child.
But they're not in color, presumably because they--

No, they would have been black and white. It c- c- it's just a digital camera cuz it's just a- they don't see in black and white so it's just like a- it's just like a... I don't know, a I thi- I think it's burnt onto the retina or sommat and, um, the only one that they've kept were the ones they saw a lot of the time.
I mean in a way, ehh, some of the "Educating Ricky" I've got for you today is- is on the similar lines.
Are- you've gotta be impressed by that. You've got to be impressed by that.
No-no, I mean, that's pretty good, I mean I- I'm interested to see, you know, what- what they do with it.
What they do- what they do with- what the crab developments are.
But, yeah, yeah, no that's- that's- that's pretty good.
Well just digest that information because that- that's not even the most impressive one we found.
I suppose it's pretty impressive but the next one's more- maybe more shocking.
Let's play a tune and then Ricky's got another extraordinary clip.
So that's the- that's the crabs that can- you can download their memories. Uhm--
But- but what about other animals that are in the sea? In that same sea, in the stuff, have they tested them yet?

I don't know. I think it- they just took it on because their, uhm, biology, uh- something to do with- I presume they can take up minerals and, you know- I don't know, why. I don't know. But anyway, uhm, next one, uhh, this is, uhh, on the horizons, umm, uhh, a bodybuilder, yeah? Umm, uhh, married--
Had another bodybuilder- married another bodybuilder--
Right, and they were pregnant. And, umm, they had these tests and the baby was very large but it was causing it pain, all right? In the- thing- in the- right? And it- after a- this is--
This is strange. It's almost bizarre in, like..
This is- yeah. After the wo- the- the f- female woke up, pregnant, after seven months and the baby ha--
No... Had forced its way out of the vagina.
Yeah. Had forced its way out.
It- it almost had, like, super strength, like--
And it was pulling her along by the umbilical cord and they had to- and it was- but it was a stone.
(Almost Laughing) Extraordinary. That- now that's freaky.
I mean, talk about freaky stuff.
Yeah, well no, it- it- she- she could feel it.
Yeah, exactly. And it was- do you know what I mean? Like, just went (Makes A Tearing Sound) and just sort of squeezed it's way--

Right, well do you know what it means?
Right. Well, years ago with, uhh- with actors in musicals and stuff--
They'd, um- the actors used to look pretty yellow on the stage cuz they didn't have proper makeup and that.
Right. So, what they used to do, uhh, to make themselves look--
Well, they got- they got bacon--
And it made the face a bit sticky cuz of all the, like, you know, the pig fat and bit of lard and stuff like that.
And then they'd go and get some bricks...
House bricks. Rub 'em together, make some sort of red dust from the brick.
And then put the dust on their face--
And the- the fat and the lard and that would make the dust stick--
And, uhhm, they'd look well... under the lights. And that's- that's where the saying--
Yeah, lovely. Everyone loves the smell of bacon.
